content.webTitle: Pauline Hanson’s One Nation triples support since election: Newspoll

fields.headline: Pauline Hanson’s One Nation triples support since election: Newspoll
fields.bodyText: Pauline Hanson’s One Nation has tripled its support since the election according to Newspoll, reaching 6% of the lower house vote around Australia and double-digit support in Queensland. A Newspoll taken between 6 and 9 October and released on Monday shows One Nation would win 6% of the national vote in the House of Representatives. That compares with 2% in a Newspoll in late August and 1.3% at the 2 July election. But One Nation’s lower house vote at the election was pushed down by the fact it only ran candidates in 12 lower house seats in Queensland and three in New South Wales. It recorded a Senate vote of 4.3% at the election nationwide. According to the Newspoll, One Nation has reached 10% lower house support in Queensland, up from 5.5% at the election, and a small increase from its Senate vote of 9.2%. According to the results One Nation would win 6% of the vote in the lower house in New South Wales and Western Australia. In those two states One Nation won 4% of the Senate vote at the election, despite not running candidates in many lower house seats. In South Australia, One Nation is polling at 4% and in Victoria at 3%, both slightly higher than in the Senate election. The Newspoll recorded the Coalition as having a primary vote of 39%, down 3% since the election and Labor with a vote of 36%, up 1.3%. The Greens were steady on 10%. The Nick Xenophon Team had 2% support, compared with 1.8% at the election. Other parties and independents were down from 9.9% at the election to 7%, suggesting One Nation’s support came at the expense of other minor parties. Appearing on Seven’s Sunrise on Monday in their joint segment, the Justice party senator Derryn Hinch congratulated Hanson for going up in the polls. Asked about One Nation’s support on 2GB Radio, the treasurer, Scott Morrison, said government “is not an easy thing” and crossbench senators didn’t face the same pressure. “I understand that people feel anxious about what is happening in the economy,” he said. “People’s wages have not been growing like they used to back in the days of John Howard and Peter Costello, since the GFC. “They feel anxious about trade … about foreign investment, and they feel anxious about foreign investment.” Morrison said the government had to control the borders and apply national interest tests to foreign investment and trade deals to reassure people. “That’s the task we’ve set ourselves – to show why that is making Australians richer, it always has over the last 200 years, but there will always be some anxious about those issues and I suspect that translates support to other political parties.” Hanson’s four Senate votes are important to the government’s legislative agenda, as it needs One Nation’s support to pass bills in the upper house if Labor and the Greens oppose them. On Wednesday the Turnbull government removed a veteran Nationals senator from the membership of a parliamentary committee to give one of its own spots to Hanson. One Nation has helped the Turnbull government pass its amendments to the Fair Work Act to deal with the Victorian Country Fire Authority dispute. The four senators will also be critical to pass two bills tightening regulation on unions, the Australian Building and Construction Commission bill and the registered organisations bill. One Nation senators have hinted that they favour a crackdown on unions but have not announced a final position. On Tuesday Hanson is going to Norfolk Island on a three-day “fact-finding mission” at the invitation of Norfolk Island People for Democracy, a group opposed to the Australian government’s revoking of the island’s autonomy.
